reviewer_review: Amazing! Excellent displays throughout. Could spend more time there than what I did so will hopefully revisit next time in London.

Loved every minute of our three hours here and had to rush the Victorians onwards as it was closing. Have to go back and do this wonderful museum justice , hope to bring my grandchildren , they would love it .
Absolutely amazing displays of artefacts. My children particularly enjoyed the Elgin Parthenon Sculptures, which were lovingly carefully displayed for the whole world to enjoy. And it's free!
History of nearly the whole world in one place with some amazing cornerstones of civilisation. Allow a lot of time so that you don’t have to rush.
The british museum is big and has a lot of wonderfuls inside. The entrance is free. The only problem is that almoust all exposed things are stolen from other countries. Manolo
A good place to visit and especially liked the Egyptian section. Unfortunately the cafe with "proper" chairs was closed at the time we visited and the only option was backless benches.

As the weather was lousy we changed our plans and decided to go central and visit this fantastic museum. It was a Saturday and of course it was busy, in fact there were queues on both sides. I'm not sure why they don't charge, I nearly said we don't charge, millions of tourists with cheap sterling experiencing all this for free. £20 at the Uffizi and £15 at the Louvre.
Anyway, we headed for Sutton Hoo and Europe, best to plan ahead, we could hardly move in some areas. Worth queuing just to see the ship burial helmet, something you won't forget. Just so much to see and to read, absolutely fascinating.
We lasted an hour and a half. I had asked one of the information assistants if there was anything he'd recommend, he said the V&A - maybe that's not quite so busy.
A museum that causes you different emotions. Many cultures together! You need a lot of time there!All the time with a lot of people.

This is definitely worthy of a visit. But there is so much to see it can be overwhelming. The Rosetta Stone is definitely something to focus on checking out. But it is not well marked, and can be obscured by the crowd of people around it.

I love this place. The permanent exhibits are beautiful and so thoughtfully curated and the visiting exhibits are always interesting and beautifully staged - however, massively oversubscribed so you'll need to get in early, both for tickets and in the day if you want to avoid the crowds. Well worth a visit at any time of year.

Admittedly, I only had about 1.5 hours to be in the British Museum after I had passed through the security line, so I zipped through a lot of the museum at speed.
I visited on a Sunday afternoon, so it wasn't as busy as it could have been, but it was still plenty busy anyway.
As a speed-visitor, I found it difficult to find certain items. First visit was to the Rosetta Stone, which I found thanks to the crowds when I had reached the correct room. Then I visited the 'library' room, which is massive and impressively beautiful! After a quick wander through the Americas section, I went to the jewel (in my opinion!) - the amazing roof architecture in the courtyard!
I know this isn't the reason to visit the British Museum, but I didn't have the time to immerse myself into the museum, and the glass canopy is truly a work of art!
I'll have to go back sometime to finish the museum off!

It's more than your mind can take in, but it's well worth spending a few hours in this place. This was certainly one of the key highlights of our London trip.The museum is set up as if you're walking through a historical timeline. It's fascinating. You'll even see things like a cup (bowl) of Artexerxes 1 (the O.T. leader Nehemiah was his cup bearer). I suggest you do some research before you go so you can take full advantage of your visit. You can see it in 2-3 hours, but I suggest you have more time, if possible.
Super crazy to see treasures from Egypt, Assyria and hunks of the Parthenon, all in the British museum. And oh yeah, the Rosetta Stone!!
Just too busy. Overrun with teenage tour groups- noisy, loud and rude. Not my favourite museum for lots of reasons.

Artefacts from planet earth have been assembled throughout the many galleries and courtyards. There are lots of stairs but also plenty of lifts to get you where you want to go. We were hoping to see relics from the Industrial Revolution after seeing an image of a ‘nocturnal’ on the cover of the museum map. Two guides were not sure what a nocturnal was or where it was in the museum. One of them suggested we try the Enlightenment collection. We didn’t find it . The museum had plenty of visitors and showed signs of needing some housekeeping. Great big shop in the Great Court and several in house eatery options to keep you going.
Only had about 2 hours to walk through parts of the Museum. I takes a few minutes to get oriented but, staff was very helpful and it was a great visit and the museum is truly amazing.

This is one of the best museums I have ever been to, it's a little overwhelming with so much stuff inside of it, but if you plan your trip there you will be fine :) It's so good and the building is beautiful!!! AND FREE!

I feel this place has been a victim of its own success. The crowds are horrendous. I wish they would charge. It’s disgusting the number of people who just walk past the donation bins. I feel a small £5 fee would be perfectly reasonable for a full day or entertainment.

Went here with a few of our choir students touring London. Very pretty architecture. The inside of the museum included mummies histories of Ancient Greece, Egypt, and more. Very interesting! And it’s free!

This is really a must-see if you're going to London. Even if you're not a huge fan of museums, and even if you only have a few hours to spare. We were only there about 4 hours on our recent trip to the UK, but it was well worth it. We had to jump around more than we would have preferred in order to see most of the "must see" artifacts, but my family was very happy we did. We even enjoyed our visit despite the fact that we had major jet lag after basically getting no sleep on our "overnight" flight. The fact that it's free means you can spend as little as one hour, three hours, or even days in the museum and enjoy it as much as you are able. That said, this museum does make one pause at some point to think, "Wow, the Brits really did appropriate a lot of stuff owned by other countries/cultures!" I know that's a very contentious issue, and no matter what side of the argument you're on you ought to go and appreciate the artifacts for what they are - regardless of their present location.

This museum was free, but I want money back for being subject to this disgusting display of thinly veiled racism.
Every exhibit is essentially "look what our friends in Canada/Australia/Africa/etc gave us as gifts"--when it should be accurate to history and admit that millions of people were slaughtered for those "gifts".
This museum is shameful.
Great to see the mummies again, really worth seeing! Japan department was also good. Long queus due to school classes from central europe

I visit the British Museum, whilst visiting London. I queued for a good while to get in but exhibitions on offer was worth the wait.
There is so much to see, so leave enough time to get around it.
You do get homeless people trying to ask for money in the queue as well. As a word of warning.
The garden outside the library is nice to relax in, during a warm day.
the artifacts are "brought" from all over the world like in many museums in London. free entrance. you can find something from your country.
Do not miss the British Museum. It is the best in the world and free. We saw the hi lights we wanted to see in 2-3 hours. Very worthwhile.

I have been wanting to see this museum for years and finally I get to have an hour and a half to enjoy some of the highlights this museum offers. Monday morning when it first opens is a perfect time because there are hardly any crowds. I was totally enthralled by the permanent collection and just so glad to have an opportunity to enjoy some of the treasures that I am not sure I would have been able to see in my lifetime. I look forward to visiting again!
Amazing architecture and great exhibitions. Everything is so well thought towards visitors. Go back every time.

There are a million of collections and masterpieces! There is just one bad point that I rent an audio guide but needed to change once due to low battery... the second one also low battery, hence I gave up to use it.....
The British Museum was incredible. It was better than any museum that I have ever visited anywhere in the world. It is a must see for you and all the family. I shall return!

Our family liked the British Museum almost as much as the Louvre, because it seemed more approachable and wasn’t as much walking for our kids. There was also no line to get in, just a quick bag check. It was our kids’ second-favorite attraction in London behind climbing to the top of St. Paul’s Cathedral.

Where else are you going to find so many exceptional exhibits. The Egyptian section is tremendously popular and is a great collection. I downloaded the recording podcasts that give you a summary of what is in each room and listened as we walked through the room Great addition to the visit - but may not be much different that the audio books you get get at the main desk.
First time visit, wonderful new building. Very user friendly. Chose to visit first the Uk and then Mesopotamia. Exhibits very interesting . A great experience.
visited twice this time and feeling not enough time to see, the people work there was friendly and very knowledgble, great for all ages.
Was so lovely to ho here but need To go back for a second vist as they is so much to see and you need a couple of hours to see everything so will be definitely going back soon cant wait

This is a ever green that you can’t miss if you’re visiting London. I suggest to take a whole day or at least half a day to visit it with calm. The gift shop inside the museum is really cute and full of nice stuff.

There was so much to see!!! Loved it! We didn't explore the whole thing because we had to leave. We planned to spend 2 hours but then we were there for almost 4 hours and didn't get to half of it all.

You could spend a day here! Unfortunately, we only had some time in the afternoon. We thoroughly enjoyed our experience, despite its ability to get lost in it! It has such a diverse set of exhibitions, that my travel partner and I were both satisfied with the content of the museum! Just being in the main hall is a work of art! This is a must see — just leave plenty of time!

My two kids (9 & 11 years old) and I visited the museum on a Tuesday late morning and spent a couple hours there. They loved seeing all the antiquities. We were only able to see a small portion of the exhibits in our visit, but a couple hours was all two young kids could manage. There were quite a few school groups there at the same time as us, with varying levels of politeness and volume control, which made the visit a little more difficult, but overall it was well worth the time. The restaurant was great, as well!
Have visited before but still overwhelmed by the stunning artefacts and exhibits with excellent supporting information. Best to visit in relatively short timescales, it gets very crowded and hot

A must see for anyone who loves history, jewelry, woodworking, painting, sculptures, artifacts from different parts of the world and centuries of differences in religion. Really need a full day to see everything in the museum. It was an amazing experience!
Only had an hour but we focused on the Egyptian room which fascinated the children giving them the thirst for more. Of course they loved the shop!
My first visit was 25 years ago and every now and then we pop in with Friends, Family, etc. An amazing place, well maintained and just adorable. Our little son loved it too. 😊
This beautiful building contains a mind boggling amount of displays from all over the world and its free to visit. Its must see attraction.
We visit whenever we are in town, there is so much to see. Pick an area or interest and concentrate on that otherwise the volume of both the exhibits and building can overwhelm. simply magnificent.
Spent a few hours at the museum
Great museum, free entrance , you can visit a few times each time another floor. Buy the guide and leave a donation.

I like the museum so much but could not visit in one day, I returned next day. I changed my whole trip and tour schedule to see the other half. Its is very nice museum and nice collections. I especially like the history of watches.

We visited on a rainy day and it was wonderful attraction to visit with kids. I do strongly recommended to get the audio. It makes it much more fun for children to look for the exhibiton pieces with audio and they do tend to learn more. There is always something interesting going on in this museums and often they have additional program for families with kids. But even if they dont, kids do have fun looking around as apart from few places it never is too crowded. Also outside there is nice area for kids to just roam free or to sit and have a coffee.
If you want something special there is lovely Afternoon Tea on the top floor.
So much to see. Make sure you have good walking shoes as to see all the exhibitions you will walk miles. You need a good 3-4 hours to see everything and the best point its FREE to get in.

Collections from whole world were gathered in this museum. you probably need at least 4 hours to finish whole museum.
entrance is free of charge.
You can either buy a well- illustrated coloured guidebook for 6 pound or audio guide for 7 pound. (i choose the guidebook as i can keep it as sourvenir, haha!)
Free of charge! Nice building to explore. We spent half a day here. Great place for all ages. Cafe inside the British museum serve reasonable food. Must visit place in London !

The British Museum is my favourite so far. The Science Museum and the Natural Historical museum,and so more accessible on small group visit.Its wonderful exhibitions are beautifully curated,one area of an ancient kingdom in great detail.
The airy central hall with places to sit and the shop in bettwen in the round makes for a welcoming place to linger.
Will be back again with our family

We did not allow even close to enough time to visit the British Museum. It is quite impressive and large. From the Rosetta Stone to countless ancient artifacts, their collection is amazing. I believe they only present 1% of their collection at a time which is a little disappointing because they have so much room, but it was still overwhelming. Most impressive is that it is free to enter and even though we went on a Saturday afternoon the crowds were tolerable. I only wish we had given ourselves more time as 2.5 hours is not enough. Disclaimer - We are big history buffs (especially Ancient Greek) so if historical things aren't your cup of tea this might not be the place for you.

It’s set out beautifully, very consumer friendly, really polite helpful security on all entrances
The exhibitions are roomy and well presented, if I was to offer any criticism (minor) non reflective glass to aid photography would help
Need a day at least to see it all.

What an immense day we had. Unbelievable. Loved finding the ‘A history of the world in a hundred objects’ exhibits. Would love it if the museum regularly did more podcasts and radio programmes like this.

Hordes of very noisy school groups constantly walk around and remain in the museum without stopping; none of the very incompetent museum staff cares about them .. (
It is not possible to focus attention. Many exhibits do not have numbers or names with notes. It takes extra time to find out what's in front of you .. (
This museum has a very chaotic atmosphere.
The museum closes at 17.20 .. (except Friday.

While I thoroughly enjoyed the various exhibits of the much--lauded British Museum--including the Ashurbanipal exhibit--I still find myself with mixed feelings regarding the inclusion of so many pieces that perhaps should be repatriated to the nations they were taken from. The pieces from the Sutton Hoo Burial Ship were a highlight, and the overall design of the museum is fantastic. Admission to the museum is free, but special exhibits require the purchase of a ticket.

If you love history then you must visit the British Museum. So much history, from around the world, you will be spoilt for choice, from the Egyptian, Aztecs to the cradle of human civilisation. My favourite was Money and the 5 Billion $ note. Enjoy

I’m from the US and very few museums are free. This fabulous museum is free to the public and you can literally spend days here. I’ve been to the Louvre and I prefer this one. You can have lunch, shop, there’s something for everyone! I’ve been 5 times and will continue to go back!

This is by far the best museum to see all the History's of the world under one roof!! Be prepared to do lots of walking. We went during the week so their were lots of school field trips going on which made it very crowded and loud.
The Egypt collections was fantastic, but the school groups would just take a seat in front of many of the exhibits and fill out their assignments which made it very difficult to get close to many of the exhibits. Overall it was a wonderful visit!!

I had made the terrible mistake of visiting the British Museum on a weekend first and it was so incredibly crowded we had to leave without visiting all the exhibitions. I returned mid-week at 15:00 to find no queues and much more relaxing to walk around. Plenty of options to eat/drink too which was pleasant.

We actually attended the “Night at the Museum” and slept overnight! It was an incredibly unique experience and worth doing once. You may not get much actual sleep, but the activities are fun and the kids had an absolute blast! We had a lot of freedom to explore the exhibits, and everyone was in good spirits, the staff was kind and had planned activities. Tips- I would HIGHLY recommend bringing warm bedding and air mattresses (only hand pumps/non-electric pumps are permitted). We slept much better with mattresses than those on the ground with only blankets. Also bring portable charger brick for your phone (plugs are not accessible), and bring a light meal like sandwiches for the 9pm “snack”. Breakfast of bakery items, fruit, and coffee/tea is provided in the morning. Our theme of the night was “Lost Kingdoms” and we slept in the Egyptian exhibit. The theme changes throughout the year and this sleepover event is held a few times per year. I’d recommend the museum for a day visit, as well!
A magnificent collection of historical items from around the world. If you are interested in history this is the place
If you’re visiting London one place you need to visit is the British Museum. Large collection of both ancient and early modern artefacts and in general an incredible museum

I have wanted to visit the Egyptology department with the museum for a long time and finally managed to get to the museum when visiting London last week. It's a must visit with lots to see and the Egyptology dept is fantastic! It's open until 8.30 pm on Fridays too!

The best way to get through it is with a plan. Egypt + the mommies, the Assyrians, Greece (fly back to Athens and now you can see what you didn’t get to see in Acropolis!) we got in at 4:15, easy walk through- no lines at all- asked to security for the sculptures we wanted to see and they pointed us in the right direction. They said they close at 5:30 but at 5:20 they were ushering people out, you have to make sure you’re done at that time. We even had time to see some of Japan’s dynasty!

A fantastic exhibition which is very informative and erudite. The pieces on show give a great insight into the life of the time. Do not rush your visit and allow plenty of time so you can take it all in!

The British Museum has many interesting areas but none more so than the Egyptology exhibits. Plan to spend the day there if you can and take your time. There are good places to eat, interesting shops and lots and lots to learn!
Come for the Rosetta Stone and stay for the amazing antiquities. With free admission you can't go wrong. Honestly one of the most amazing museums I've ever been to.
Wonderful place to spend the day. proves that the best things in life are free. Enjoyed the Egyptian rooms and the Islamic art. Also the new islamic gallery

I'd obviously heard a great deal about the British Museum before I visited, so was already keen to see what it had to offer...
But good God, it was amazing! There was so much there that it would take hours to see all of it, from Mummies and Assyrian statues to Samurai armour and Aztec stonework. This place is an awe-inspiring celebration of humanity, and a must-see attraction for anyone with the slightest interest in history!

I visited the British Museum for the first time last July after nearly living in the UK for seven years. I was upset with myself for not having been before. My usual two hour time in a museum turned into nearly five hours with me wandering the many collections this museum has to offer.
This is truly a History Lovers Paradise, and a History Lover I am indeed! The variety of collections and the different cultures and times that are represented are extensive. It is well worth a whole afternoon visit if in London.
This place has the collections from ancient Greece and the Middle East. A fantastic display of artifacts and a must see museum in London.

We visited the museum whilst staying in Russell Square. I wish we had done a little research before we went. This museum has so much to see and its pretty much impossible to do all in a day. It’s probably best to pick an area to concentrate on or certain artefacts. It’s an impressive building with an abundance of things to see. It’s airy and light with both stairs and lifts. There are several areas to have a coffee but not many places to sit! Absolutely would recommend and will definitely plan another visit soon.

Very well laid out Museum with lots of interest. exhibitions are excellent . Cafe good but not an expansive menu but what was on offer was good. helpful staff and lots of seating areas as the area to cover and stand up is large.
I have always loved the BM. I took my 9 year old daughter to London for her first time last week, and she was thrilled with the vast collection of Egyptology, her absolute favorite!!

My sister had been insisting for a few days because this museum is practically minutes away from her flat. So I got dressed, had my breakfast and went to see it. I was speechless. It is beautiful as a piece of historical architecture, it is huge (it takes more than one day to see it all) and it is free to get in. Those of you who love history from anywhere in the world and is your first time in London would be those I would encourage to get up early and try to be the first to get in. Close to the tube station and easy to get to on foot once you arrive at Tottenham Court Road. There are many different things to see and seeing them more than once does not make you tired. You learn to see them from different angles. Mine are: I wonder how long it took you to be made? I wonder how long it took for you to be here? I wonder if I will look cool with a picture of this place as my profile (it is such a beautiful place). Serene, elegant and huge. Enjoy your visit and hope you agree. Thanks.

The British Museum is absolutely enormous and is sure to impress all visitors. Even after two separate visits of a few hours each, I have yet to see the whole museum! I would recommend coming over the course of a few days to space out the exhibits and avoid getting exhausted. I was also impressed that the museum is completely free! Given the sheer quantity and quality of exhibits, it feels like a privilege to enter free of charge. If you want to avoid the crowds, visit during the week.

This museum is free, so just go and view what you want to see. There were a lot of tour groups, even in March, so be prepared for a crowd. It’s not a traditional art museum, more like an artifacts museum, so don’t go in expecting to see paintings.

A 15 minute walk from Kings Cross, just off Russell Square. It is free to enter and because time was limited for us, we had a list of what we wanted to see. The Rosetta Stone, Elgin Marbles, Egyptian Mummies and Easter Island statue to name a few. There is a bag search on the way in and you can take a picnic or eat at one of the various cafes and restaurants. There are also guided tours which you can book onto as well as audio self guide equipment. If your in London make this top of your list of things to do, after all it is the largest and possibly the best museum in the world.
Confusing lay out. Odd lighting that made you feel like you had vertigo. Free but a staff member standing next to a box asking for £5,10 or 20. Reasonable few hours but not what I was expecting
Magnificent place. If you visit London, don't miss! this place. Love the Egyptian Antiquities. Other part of museum is great too! (visited UK in 2017 & 2018)

A very big, very varied museum. For a more rounded experience, it’s better than Science or Natural History. Contains The Rosetta Stone, Elgin Marbles to name a few. Lots of Mummies, Greek and Roman artifacts.
Excellent museum. My favorite part was the Egyptian antiquities. The collection is wonderful; although, controversial.
This museum was super enriching and very interesting, for young and old alike. I recommend this magnificent place which is worth a visit.

Probably the best museum I’ve ever visited. I can easily spend days in it. Highly recommend getting the book “Through The British Museum with the Bible” while visiting for anyone interested in seeing how archeology reveals the trustworthiness of the Bible.

This museum has a lot to show, from objects to Egyptian mummies and Greek/Roman statues.
There are many rooms, so that it takes such 2 hours to see everything in the inside.
But it's free to visit; so why not going there? People will seem to be in many parts of the world, from Asia to Europe and America.

The British museum is stocked from around the world with some of the best museum pieces in the world.
Much of the content was acquired during the British Empire so maintaining a degree of political sensitivity.
Unique artefacts such as the Rosetta stone attract a lot of attention, as do the Egyptian and Assyrian collections.
Great place for all the family and well planned to be engaging with some staff explaining exhibits. A must to see!

It was a huge place with endless rooms full of artifacts. We did not visit during peak holiday season and yet we found it to be crowded with tour groups especially on the ground floor. We did not purchase an audio guide and found ourselves wandering aimlessly, distracted by the crowd, which was a pity.
This is a place worth repeated visits and best done with audioguide and/or conducted tour. One just gets overwhelmed if only a few hours are allocated for a hurried visit.

The most wonderful experiences come when expectations are low. I didn’t know what to expect, but every room offers another fascinating glimpse into the past. there isn’t time to view everything but because it’s free admission you can make as many visits as you like. Always a wonderful experience of discovery.
Must see... With Family. Beautiful inside and outside. Great exhibits. Free!! The various sections of the museum are excellent.

its too easy to feel as if you are drowning in culture when you visit these vast emporiums of ancient artefacts, its as if you become anesthetized and all you can see are scratches on rocks and 'old things'. The British Museum is like that but it is one of the great museums the world has ever created. Take my advice. Do some research before you go and decide on one room or one period to focus on. Don't worry if you miss things but try to really see one or two things clearly.They will stick in your memory as joys as opposed to a 'yea , did that, bought the teeshirt' cynical response. How about spending a half hour per visit over a few days in this brilliant building rather than one long visit.
The building and artifacts are all fantastic and well worth a visit. Don't forget to visit the Library!

It had a very long queue but it went fast, we didn't have to wait for too long. and surprisingly the entrance was for FREE!
I recommend you take the audio guided tour as it is huge and you need either to know where exactly you want to go

Check out the Rosetta Stone, full Egypt exhibit and don’t leave without a quick view of pieces of the Parthenon. Loved walking around among so much history! And The British Museum is free admission! But I definitely recommend leaving a few bucks to help them keep it free for all. Great spot!

This place is chock full of historic finds including the controversial "Elgin Marbles" from the Parthenon in Athens. Greece wants them back and it has been ever thus since the early 19th century. Lord Elgin was in Athens and arranged to run off with a bunch of marble statues from various parts of the pediments and side friezes of the Parthenon, the centerpiece of the Acropolis and a major tourist attraction in Athens. British Museum will not let them go and its argument is strong: there are many other museums all over the world including Denmark and the Vatican which have pieces of the Parthenon. Why should they be returned? What of the people who can't make it to Athens to see the Parthenon? Of course there is also the Rosetta Stone, but it you want to see its face unobstructed, get there very early when the Museum opens or go late in the day when crowds thin out.
I have visited the Museum twice before I returned on my last trip, I'm especially interested in the Lewis Men, which I have seen all now in all their locations

At the Rosetta Stone shop we bought 19 pounds worth of items with a US dollar credit card, and later saw the bill had added a 5% surcharge, probably from the BM first converting to USD at a 5% rate without asking as is usual "charge in GBP or in USD?" or charging in just GBP. In addition the shopkeeper kept BOTH the BM's and the customer copy of the credit card receipt, and refused to hand over the customer receipt after several requests. Advice: pay cash to people at the BM! We feel deceived.

We did a whirlwind tour of the museum using the Rick Steve's audioguide to Europe app and it was very informative and best of all, free. The museum is lovely and well organized. The biggest draw is no doubt the Rosetta Stone. We went in the afternoon and there were a lot of people but we got to see everything we wanted to see. Make sure you budget time before entering to have your bags searched for sharp objects. I think in high season the line can be quite long.

This is a an excellent museum, free of charge, in the very center of London. Very good art works from various artists spread on centuries. Easy access to and from the metro station, very nice personnel.

The best museum I've ever been! Place is huge, and take 2-3 hours to see all these fantastic stuff. If you want to avoid crowd, I recommend to be there early in the morning. Also, buy a map for easy navigation.

A brilliant day out for the whole family. Very busy but you can totally see why. The Egyptian part was brilliant. Audio guides were available and staff were very helpful. The queue for the toilets was ridiculous. Book shop was fantastic and would recommend a cake from the cafe.
Very well organized, a lot of info, very well presented. I am Greek so I would prefer the marbles from Acropolis to be where they belong and have identical copies at the museum.
If yuo are looking to show the teens history ,look no further then this great museum with plenty to do and see!

It's easy to get lost in here as there is so much to see and one room seamlessly leads to the other. Be sure to use the provided map to isolate what you really want to see if you don't have much time. Hard to not find something of interest in this place!
The architecture is just fantastic and the displays are excellent. The Egyptian areas are very good.

this by far is our favorite museum in london. there is such a wide variety of artifacts including the rosetta stone and the bodies of ancient man recovered from peat bogs. there is evolution explanations of the ancient man to modern day man and their eras. simply amazing. i could spend all day here. there are more relatable artifacts here more so than paintings and sculptures. extremely interesting. loved it.
The various exhibitions which i have been to have all.been excellent and as a member they are all free.
A wonderful museum and experience. You need a full morning or full afternoon to be able to see it all. Do not forget to visit the gift shop - it is a must as well!
The most of the museum is about other nations.. Greeks, Romans, Egyptians, etc.. The best exhibits are the greek ones.. Really sad..
With so much to see, we opted for the 90 minute guided tour, which enabled us to see and understand a bit about many of the highlights. Definitely a good choice.
I have been here with my family a few days ago , and we were really surprised , how much time you can spend here , a couple of hours ... At least ! So many things to see ! Brilliant !

This place is extremely big! There are so many different types of historical venues from countries around the world. Not only is it free but you could probably spend an entire day and not be able to visit it all.
Thank you very much for the great exhibition and nice restaurants and great time and beautiful atmosphere
We spent a couple of hours in the museum and enjoyed viewing the various exhibits.. Worth a visit! We enjoyed the S.E Asia section with its huge Chinese and Indian artifacts!

One of the world's most famous museums and its fame is well deserved. Outstanding collection from all over the world, from ancient times to recent years. Prepare for the long queues before the entrance, the museum is free and it makes a very popular attraction.

Used to take the kids literally every weekend to the British Museum. Wonderful place to spend personal time with the family. Pack some sandwiches and crisps and you are on your way. Great place for kids (and adults) to learn new things. No substitute for first hand knowledge. Great thing about this place is that they regularly hold special events and exhibitions...……...always something happening! If anything it is a lovely place just to chill out and the added bonus of spending quality time with family.
Great place to spend a few hours in the afternoon whilst a brief visit to London. Enjoyed throughly the site. Well kept, staff helpful and informative.

If you want to see artifacts from al over the world, this is the place to be. All the cultures from antiquity to today. Pure history. The entrance is free pf charge, but if you want to support, you can donate.

I regularly stay at the Bedford Hotel which is a short walk from the British Museum. However, it was only last month that I went to visit the museum. I wish I had dropped in before.
The museum is very large and it is impossible to see very much in a single visit. We went early at opening time but there were still long queues. The queues did move quickly and that should not put anybody off. There is so much to see you could visit every day for a week and still not see everything.
I have made up my mind to visit every time I stay at the Bedford Hotel. Even a short visit of half an hour is worthwhile.

Access not so good, narrow doorways with everyone funnelled through. Space within each gallery was good but in some, particularly the Rembrandt exhibit where there was shelving in front of the pieces with the the art description obscured by it, I couldn’t see it from my wheelchair. Staff in general nice and willing to help. I went to the toilet, accessed through the shop, joined the que being encouraged to hurry by a staff member, she advised the toilets where blocked and all alternative toilets closed, I asked, “ including the disabled? “ her response was to ask the young mother with her child if she was disabled and told her I had to go 1st. I was so embarrassed for her, I thought you were not allowed to ask that question!! Many shops and cafes. It was so difficult to get around the shop in my wheelchair and looking around able people had difficulty moving around between displays also.
Having looked forward to this visit for many years I was left disappointed.

Very very big place I don't think we saw half of the items on show. Thought it was quite a complicated set up. (Or I'm just stupid). What we did see was very well exhibited and small boards explained what it was. Thoroughly enjoyed it. Very busy so go early.
One of the most beautiful museums that I've seen ! Everything so well organised ,very clean and very big. Prepare for minimum 3 hours of knowledge

Overwhelmed my expectations. The best way to spent at least a day. Regrets that i didn't had more time, but definitely worth it, even for a short visit. Mine around 6 hours was really good small bite.

Haven't visited for many years and was very impressed. The range of exhibits is amazing and requires many visits to appreciate them. Good to follow the short trip recommended in the free guide. The Parthenon Marbles are especially good.

I am not really a museum person but if you like museums this is not one to miss. The collection is extensive and entry is free. The museum is located in central London so you can enjoy the area around the museum. Do give yourself enough time if you want to enjoy your visit as it is quite large.

Our group only had an hour here. There are many wonderful things to see and wish we could have seen more. Definitely pick up a map of the museum and prioritize what exhibits you’d like to see. The museum is laid out well making it fairly easy to find your way around.
If you like looking at stolen stuff then this is your place. Needs more Fortnite stuff. The gift shop should sell real swords
Well what are you know... wooow what a collection of history in one place, make you whana realize we are all dust in the wind and what's the point of the lust for power and money?!

My family and I visited early one afternoon, and were overwhelmed by the depth of some of the collections and exhibits.
I accidentally leaned against a “cursed” Egyptian sarcophagus, and nothing terribly bad has happened as of yet.
The Rosetta Stone was impressive to see in person.
An Easter Island Moai Statue was a pleasant surprise.
My daughter especially liked the Greek section.
The Great Wave off Kanagawa was not on display.
A lot of statues appendages and heads missing; irony for me was that one statue, assumed to be a wine drinker, was missing the forearm/hand actually holding the wine.
The British sometimes catch some flak for being great “collectors” - but I saw some restorations that were good for all - piles of rubble meticulously restored for many to see in close to their original state.
It is an amazing museum that you should visit well-rested. To see all the rooms, you should dedicate at least three-four hours . Waiting queu is very long but really fast. And it is free of charge!
Admission is completely free, but what you see inside the museum can be worth hundreds of dollars, best free experience!
It was truly an amazing experience. I'm so impressed with Egyptian exhibits. It was quite busy on Sunday but still worth spending a day there.

We just visited ancient Rome and Greece and were totally consumed and exhausted after 4 hours of deep rich education into ancient life on display. Bring a camera. The architecture of the museum is as stunning as the exhibits. Open floor cafe and a full restaurant for dining as well.
Return the parthenon marbles and everything that is stolen from Athens. It's a shame..... nice museum with stolen exhibits.

I visited on a school trip when I was in high school nearly 25 years ago. So much of the museum has remained unchanged in that time (Parthenon room and mummies).
My kids enjoyed the mummies and the Japanese exhibit most. It was a long day so we only spent a few hours. I can imagine being lost in this museum for much longer than that if time had allowed.
It was an overall nice museum. It had lots of cool artifacts. It had a nice entrance. It also had a nice layout.
Best museum in London, so much to see in every single room. The Egyptian room is phenomenal and I believe the building is 5 stories.. jampacked with fun education

I visit The British Museum every time I am in London. The beauty of this place is that admission is free. You can stop in and see just a few rooms if your time is limited. If you've got a half day, you can see all of the important things. I like to see the mummies and my favorite guy, Lindow Man. The museum is laid out well and the gift shop offers great gifts and books if you'd like to learn more about the things you saw during your visit. All in all, a great experience for all ages.
Guided tour and it was awesome. The kids really enjoyed it. So much to see and do. Makes history fun and exciting. Beautiful foyer. Well displayed. Could have spent days walking around

We visited to support my daughter's school work on the Romans but saw so much more. We have since re-visited just for pleasure. Just a lovely place to look around, learn or just look and like. The atrium is amazing - I just stood and looked up for several minutes! Didn't try the cafe but I might another time.

This is one of my favourite. Lovely building full of history. I love the Egyptian rooms, but also the Romans history and the Parthenon from Greece. The shops have nice souvenirs too, Cleopatra’s pen was a must for me!
What a fantastic place, so much to do and see, and so much history going back hundreds of years, you could easily get lost in history for hours and hours.

This is a wonderful museum with something to offer every age group, and to return to time and again. There is always something you have not seen, and the range of exhibition rooms is so diverse, from the Marbles to the Assyrians...Rodin to modern art.. Lots of places in the museum to sit and have coffee and cake, plenty of spaces to sit and admire the building itself, helpful and knowledgeable staff always on hand to guide you.. every trip provides a new delight...
Add this museum to your bucket list when traveling to London. It has so many collection from many different parts of the world. Worth to visit
This is one of my favourite places to visit while in London. The bast amount of history in this place is unbelievable. My favourite room is the Parthenon one!

Used this to meet colleagues and discuss work.
It’s great in the quiet times (not half term!)
The acoustics are nice, and it is also great to have walking meetings and discuss things, prompted by the wonderful surroundings. I also use this space to do walking coaching.

Visited for a particular exhibition but found ourselves wanting to explore the museum further. The entry was a bit chaotic and it was not clear where to go, what payment was needed and where to go next. When reaching the exhibition we were amply rewarded by the excellence of the displays.
We spent a couple of hours here but you could spend a lot longer. There is no charge but we were more than happy to make a donation as there is so much to see.

At the British Museum I’m reminded of my insignificance in the great river of humanity. Here, all that remains of once great men are a mummified corpse, a chipped marble statue, or bare bones beside the skeleton of a sword. Forgotten armies march on porcelain and stone, their deeds and deaths forgotten. And then herds of school children descend upon me and contemplation becomes futile so I retreat to the museum restaurant for a lunch of fish and chips. In time the crowds diminish, freeing me to roam once more, communing with the long departed, and marveling at the Rosetta Stone.

I love going to this museum. It is always changing with new exhibits or new ways to display old items. Unfortunately the Rosetta Stone is now enclosed in glass so can't be touched but other than that, the museum is still wonderful.

It’s the British Museum, repository of some of the worlds finest artefacts. Go early.
DO NOT attempt it all in one visit - pick a couple of sections, three tops and give them a bit of time. Egypt and Assyria are my favourites, then the Mexican room and Islamic arts.
Food court can be a bit of a noisy nightmare and it’s not cheap - take sandwiches
The world's best - very few the world over come anywhere near it. Not to be missed. Again free except for special exhibitions.

Our grandson and us had thought one visit day visit would be enough but we went back twice more.So much to discover and learn and so well display. People of the BM are so helpful and made our visits exciting and acquiring so much knowledge.

Is it the greatest museum in the world? I don’t honestly know; I haven’t seen all the others. But it’s certainly one of the greatest. The breadth and depth of its collections, the wonderful temporary exhibitions they put on, the lectures, the bookshop.
Have a quick tour of the whole place or spend a whole day concentrating on one area. Whatever you do will expand your knowledge of the human experience, if you make the effort.
The biggest and best museum in the world! Need a whole day here, and arrive early! A museum of the world and history spanning over 2000 years

We went here on a whim and enjoyed ourselves. Lots of interesting artefacts unfortunately lacking in explanations and details. We spent just over 3 hours here looking in the different halls. Was enjoyable as it was free! Most enjoyed the Mayan section.

Always my favourite place to visit when I’m in London. This trip was no exception. I particularly enjoyed The Americas galleries. The Mexican gallery is wonderfully designed to create the impression for being within a stepped pyramid.

From the imposing façade and entrance through to the spectacular main hall the British Museum is a wonderful place to spend time. In particular the ancient civilization rooms - Egyptian, Babylonian, Greek and Roman - are impressive and give great insight. You can pop in and view a few favourite displays or lose yourself for days here.

A fantastic museum… we spent a few hours looking around the exhibits that interested us most, but we could have spent days in there!
On top of that, the building is beautiful, there are some good restaurants and cafes inside, and the gift shop actually has some great products for sale, rather than just the usual tourist tat.
I love this place Especially the Egyptian gallery the Parthenon. The entrance free and I suggest to take the Audio guide as it gives you more informations cost around £5-£7

There is so much to see in the British Museum, it can’t be done on one trip really. I love the Egyptian Rooms and also the unique Rosetta Stone. There are hundreds of other priceless artifacts to see as well. A worthwhile visit for anyone interested in history and culture.

Awesome museum but an advance plan to carry or alternatively spend there all day. There are plenty of cafes and snack spots in the museum, no real restaurants were found. There are no toilets on every floor so families with children should look to their locations beforehand.

So we after thinking about things to do in London, my father and I decided it’d be great to go to the British Museum since we hadn’t been in nearly a decade.
It was a wonderful day out since there is more then enough to see in the museum, in fact it would take quite a couple of visits to be able to see the whole museum as there are plenty of area filled with many artefacts and knowledge.
All in all, it is always worth a visit and you’ll be sure to have a great time, even with young children as there is something for everyone, there is also a lovely cafe at the entry of the museum which sell lovely cakes and coffees but mind out; the prices are a tad on the expensive side.
It was absolutely fabulous! We walked there from our hotel, met our friends, and had a great day visiting Elgin's marbles.

The British Museum is a very large museum and was free to enter. A donation was an option. So many exhibits to see, so impossible to see in one visit. It is a facility where by it would be best to see different sections on multiple visits. We walked from the Tube to the Museum and found it frustrating that there was not some street signs indicating that such a prominent attraction was near by resulting in walking a far greater distance than required. As a tourist on a tight time frame this was an issue.
There is nothing like a monumental museum visit to let you know you are in England. Wow. Just wow. Put this on your top of list to visit when you get here...
Great place to visit. Has some amazing stuff to see. I don't think you can see it all in one day its huge.
Excellent items on show that prove bible history pertaining to the Persian and the Cyrus cylinder, Rosetta Stone and the Syrian Room.

I know it is a different "market", but having just been to the Natural History Museum, the British Museum sets the standard others should aspire to, in my view.
The layout, the displays, the information are all first class, and wandering around was a pleasure. Even the tea we had was in a better environment, served by more agreeable people and of better quality.
An amazing incredible place to visit. Well worth getting there first thing in the morning, firstly to avoid the queue but also to give yourself enough time to see things. You will want to go again.

If you are into history and knowledge of all things worldly then this is a compulsory stop when in London.
There is an absolutely vast array of exhibits and artefacts to see, beautifully displayed and all designed to enhance and provoke your interest in history, from our ancient ancestors through to modern times, covering the Egyptians, Romans, Japanese and much more.
The actual building and inside, both amazing, are in themselves worth seeing and experiencing.
As others have said make plenty of time to take it all in properly. Also younger children can get a bit bored, although they do fast track you through the entrance queues :)

Now matter where you are from, chances are you find something new to see in the British Museum, things that you may have read about in school or novels. The place is so large, you could easily visit every month for a year and maybe just about see everything. The paid exhibitions are excellent, though I recommend the annual membership, which gives you access to the free cloakroom, all exhibitions, the members room/cafe and 10% discount on purchases.

Most museums are very similar and so is this one, but I still love the opportunity to see history from around the world in one place at one time and the British museum does not disappointed for that. They had a lot of great Greek mythology type exhibits which happen to be my favorites. It is also nice that it is free to go into as are a lot of the museums in London. Whether you have a couple hours or the whole day it's worth it to take a walk through.
Stunning architecture ... beautiful glass dome roof. Eyptian mummies and statues. Great to see a copy of the Rosetta Stone close up .
Lovely day out and food was rest good its a goid day out for families and friends and to have tea coffee lunch cakes are really nice too
Had an amazing time, Please spend 15 mins analysing the paper map copy, then decide what do you want to see as it's a massive place. Tiring after some time. There is nice cafe too. Enjoy.
Good place to visit - I would love to return - would need to spend longer there however too much to experience in one visit

I was floored by the scope of this museum. It's like nothing I've seen before. I was here with a group learning about Christian history, so we mainly looked at the ancient middle eastern artifacts, but we barely scratched the surface in the hour or so we were there. I could easily have spent an entire day just in that wing. I hope to go back some day to see more of their seemingly endless collection. The line was a bit long to go through the security check, but they moved very efficiently. Once inside, it really wasn't too crowded because it's so large. I would call this a must-see for a visit to London!
They always have something of interest, please take your children so they can see what real books look like.
I wonder how long it will be until some 'Brexit' history will be shown in here? I do love learning about our 'great' history though!
